awd_titl_txt: FW-HTF: Whole-body Exoskeletons for Advanced Vocational Enhancement (WEAVE)
awd_abstract_narration:
The Future of Work at the Human-Technology Frontier (FW-HTF) is one of 10 new Big Ideas for Future Investment announced by NSF. The FW-HTF cross-directorate program aims to respond to the challenges and opportunities of the changing landscape of jobs and work by supporting convergent research. This award fulfills part of that aim, by examining whether and how a new technology can improve worker productivity, safety, and well-being. 

Powered, full-body exoskeletons have the potential to augment human physical capacity, thereby increasing productivity and lowering injury risks, while also preserving human skill for operating in dynamic, unstructured environments. Exoskeletons could also allow people with different physical abilities the opportunity to enter and stay employed in physically-demanding occupations.  This project will complete critical fundamental research necessary to make exoskeletons effective for augmenting human performance in industrial use, such as manufacturing and warehousing. The project also examines the potential impacts this new technology may have on the sociotechnological landscape of jobs and workers.  The team will develop a new control interface and an intelligent cognitive assistant to make exoskeleton use natural and intuitive, thus minimizing learning time and enabling adaptation to dynamic environments. The multimodal control interface will allow for augmentation of a user's perception and cognition when using physical capacity augmentation systems, and adaptive control of assistance from the exoskeleton according to user and context. The end results of this research will help workers to operate efficiently and seamlessly in dynamic and information-rich industrial settings. Industrial adoption of exoskeletons can have broad-reaching social and economic implications: by understanding the ramifications of this new technology for workforce diversification and labor market outcomes, the research will facilitate technology design choices that benefit the U.S. economy and U.S. workers. Collaboration with industry partners, including Sarcos Robotics and General Electric, will further insure industrial relevance of this project. 

This project will advance knowledge and state-of-the-art in exoskeleton control, human-robot cooperation, human factors, and augmented reality systems. An augmented reality interface to improve the user's mental model of exoskeleton capabilities and increase situational awareness will be developed, thereby enabling users to formulate new work strategies only afforded by the newly extended physical capabilities. In terms of human-robot cooperation, an adaptive predictor-based controller of high-level exoskeleton assistance parameters will be developed. This will account for the time varying response of the human to the system and the potential for different steady-state characteristics depending on the user, so as to achieve a tightly-coupled human-in-the-loop system. The assessments of learning and adaptation across a diverse range of workers will be key to making the developed designs more inclusive and effective, and to elucidating the effects of exoskeleton technologies on workforce diversification, including people with cognitive and physical impairments. While the impact of automation (replacing workers with technology) has been extensively studied in the economics literature, this work will generate the first empirical models of the effects of augmentation on worker productivity and well-being, industry profits, and the labor market in general.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goals of this project were to advance the state-of-the-art in human-exoskeleton collaboration by designing and evaluating adaptive control of exoskeleton assistance parameters and building an intuitive human-machine interface, for operating whole-body powered exoskeletons (WB-PEXO) for industrial use. We also aimed to elucidate the impacts of exoskeletons on workforce diversification and broadening labor participation, by assessing learning, usability, trust, synchrony and performance costs/benefits of exoskeleton systems across diverse target groups, and model the economic implications of technology adoption.

The project made significant contributions to the proposed objectives. Specifically, a novel whole-body control approach was developed for adaptive control of powered exoskeletons, to meet multiple objectives simultaneously, while using a whole-body, real-time dynamic model of the entire system. This approach enabled the control development for the project and is a framework that can be extended to many more future developments with powered exoskeletons. A shared-autonomy control scheme was designed, as a way to transfer autonomy back and forth between a user and the physically attached powered exoskeleton, while accomplishing a task together. A theoretical hierarchical stability approach and Lyapunov-stable tracking were developed, to allow for stability guarantees of single tasks, or a set of sub-tasks, within a multi-objective controller for shared human-robot objectives. The objective is defined in real-time, based solely on the physical input of the human to the exoskeleton, indicating the user’s intention and desired level of autonomy. An augmented-reality based visualization platform was developed, to enable research and translation in training, configuration, and operation of WB-PEXO.

Multiple user studies were completed to qualitatively and quantitatively evaluate the effects of a robot-led vs. shared-autonomy controllers for powered exoskeleton control, demonstrating the relative tradeoffs between different control approaches. We quantified human performance, biomechanics, motor adaptation patterns, perceptual-and-control strategies, and cognitive workload while operating novel exoskeleton systems, in multiple studies involving >100 human-subject participants, across diverse age, gender, and experience groups. The concepts of agency and adaptation were explored from a social-science perspective, by extending the dyadic power theory to capture synchrony and power-dynamics between human users and powered exoskeletons. These experiments were part of the design-iteration cycle and contributed to improvements in the adaptive control approaches described above. These studies have contributed to the development of new methods and metrics for evaluating the effects of exoskeleton use, and for modeling the impacts of exoskeleton design tradeoffs on human health and safety.

We undertook significant efforts to expand the user-demographics that exoskeletons are typically studied for. We explored the preferences of users from diverse age and gender groups, and characterized differences in how they perceive and react to different exoskeleton design concepts including various device form, weight, assistance mechanisms and human-exoskeleton interfaces. While all adults showed similar performance, these studies showed the specific mechanisms by which older adults compensated for any age-related deficits, through application of greater physical and mental effort. Additionally, we developed and shared a perspective piece on engaging the disability community in the design, implementation, and policymaking of industrial exoskeletons.

Finally, we have completed several studies on technology adoption and socioeconomic impact of robotics and AI. For example, we explored the consequences of the rise in industrial robots on shifts in employment in the US, and found that the effect of robotization on the labor force participation is negative for men and unmarried women but positive for married women. The impacts of AI and other advanced technologies on workers’ mental health and perceived working conditions were also explored.

The project has significantly contributed to STEM student and workforce training and professional development through various initiatives. Seventeen graduate and twelve undergraduate students in the disciplines of robotics, biomechanics, human factors, communication, economics, systems and information engineering were supported through the project.  Students were trained with convergence research principles to: appreciate scientific challenges in related disciplines outside of their core, understand how their own work may impact these other disciplines, develop multi-objective functions for problem solving, and learn how to effectively communicate research findings to appeal to the broader community of research and practice. The extensive networks of co-authorship across disciplines in this grant, and the range of dissemination outlets pursued in our publications, are a testament to our convergence approach.

In addition to dissemination through standard scientific conference and journal publications, the project team has disseminated key findings broadly through technology demonstrations at manufacturing expos, by giving invited talks, and organizing presentations to manufacturing industry partners. Through these various efforts, the team has shared research findings, identified key issues for practical exoskeleton implementations, promoted awareness on the benefits and limitations of occupational exoskeleton use, and the need for standardizing training and implementation protocols.

Thus, this project was designed and executed by means of a convergent, use-inspired approach, to pioneer the use of human augmentation technologies such as exoskeletons to improve the competitiveness of the US manufacturing work and workforce
